column2: *SOMETHING WENT WRONG*
Hi, *{{user_name}}*! I know you've used the internet before - but have you ever wondered what goes into showing you all those web pages?
I was wondering that, one day, and I decided to go find out. There was a ton to learn, but now that I've done the legwork, I can pass it on to you.
Before I explain anything, let's get you looking at the guts of a web page.
The page should open for you, but if it doesn't, you can try running Chrome...
Or you can click this link - https://codepen.io/madetohack/pen/BaaNeXj?editors=1000#code-area
OK! Here we are. The left-hand side of the page is showing you the code that the page is written in...
...And the right side is the page that you'd see if you found the page on the internet.
So, you can see that, just like computer programs, web pages are written in a form of code - It's called HTML, which stands for (get ready, it's a whopper)...
*HyperText Markup Language*
That sounds complicated, but (trust me!) it's not that bad. Hypertext is a word that describes text that can link to other text.
You already know how that works since you've clicked links before. You were practically born knowing it!
Markup Language is the way you describe a set of codewords that you stick around text to show the computer how to display them.
So it's not that bad, actually.
Let's take a look at some actual HTML! Click this link: https://codepen.io/madetohack/pen/BaaNeXj?editors=1000#code-area
OK, here you are - if you want to revert all your changes, you can just refresh the page in your browser and it'll go back like this.
Check out the text in the left-hand part of the window - that's the HTML code. I've put a TON of comments in to explain what all the parts do.
In HTML, everything with `<` and `>` around it is called a *tag*. Tags tell the browser how to display something - text, images, whatever.
Tags usually come in pairs - an `<opening tag>`, and a `</closing tag>`, like saying *start* and *stop*
Let's get our hands dirty! Find the text *Hello, World!* on the page, and change it. Add you name, your favorite food, whatever you like.
Awesome! You just edited a webpage, so that makes you a web designer!

tags in the code? Try changing the text between some of those tags...
Nice job! I hope you're starting to see that HTML isn't quite as confusing as it seems. Come back for the next activity and we'll go deeper!
